name: AI Strategy Ontology Glossary
description: Comprehensive glossary of all terms, entities, properties, and relationships in the AI Strategy Ontology

hasDefinedTerm.name: Capability
hasDefinedTerm.description: An organizational ability to perform specific activities or deliver value, particularly in the context of AI and digital transformation. Capabilities represent what an organization CAN do, encompassing technical skills, processes, resources, and knowledge required to execute strategic objectives.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Example: 'Machine Learning Model Development' capability with maturity level 'Managed', enabling predictive analytics for customer insights.
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when defining what an organization can do, assessing capability maturity, identifying capability gaps, or determining requirements for opportunities.
hasDefinedTerm.businessMeaning: Capabilities are the building blocks of competitive advantage. They represent what makes an organization effective in its market and determine which opportunities can be pursued successfully.
hasDefinedTerm.technicalMeaning: A structured entity with properties including maturityLevel (5-level CMMI-style scale), strategicImportance, dependencies on other capabilities, and relationships to enabling technologies.
hasDefinedTerm.constraints: Must have unique capabilityId, maturityLevel follows progression (Initial→Developing→Defined→Managed→Optimizing), cannot have circular dependencies with other capabilities.
hasDefinedTerm.relationships: Organization hasCapability Capability, Capability dependsOnCapability Capability, Capability enabledByTechnology Technology, Capability revealsGap Gap
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use Capability entities to: (1) assess organizational readiness for opportunities, (2) identify capability gaps through comparison with requirements, (3) map technology needs, (4) prioritize capability development investments, (5) perform competitive benchmarking.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Gap
hasDefinedTerm.description: A deficiency or absence between current and desired state of a capability, market position, or strategic objective. Gaps represent opportunities for improvement, competitive vulnerabilities, or risk areas that require strategic attention and resource allocation.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Example: Gap in 'AI Model Explainability' capability—current state: basic logging, desired state: full model interpretability with stakeholder dashboards. Severity: High, estimated 6 months to close.
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when identifying shortfalls in capabilities, documenting strategic deficiencies, prioritizing improvement initiatives, or analyzing competitive weaknesses.
hasDefinedTerm.businessMeaning: Gaps are strategic vulnerabilities that create risk or missed opportunity. Critical gaps threaten competitive position and require immediate attention. All gaps should have closure plans (Initiatives).
hasDefinedTerm.technicalMeaning: Entity capturing current vs. desired state delta with severity classification, impact assessment, and estimated closure cost/time. Links to Capabilities that reveal the gap and Initiatives that address it.
hasDefinedTerm.constraints: Must define both currentState and desiredState (non-empty strings), severity must be classified, critical gaps should have addressing initiatives (business rule validation).
hasDefinedTerm.relationships: Capability revealsGap Gap, Gap createsOpportunity Opportunity, Initiative addressesGap Gap
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use Gap entities to: (1) automatically identify gaps through capability assessment, (2) prioritize gaps by severity and impact, (3) recommend initiatives to close gaps, (4) track gap closure progress, (5) correlate gaps with competitive disadvantages.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Position
hasDefinedTerm.description: Strategic market position of an organization relative to competitors within a specific market segment or capability domain. Position represents competitive standing, differentiation, and relative strength/weakness in the competitive landscape.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Example: Position as 'Challenger' in 'AI-Powered Customer Analytics' market, positioned between market leader and fast followers, with differentiation in real-time processing capabilities.
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when assessing competitive standing, defining market positioning strategy, comparing against competitors, or tracking position evolution over time.
hasDefinedTerm.businessMeaning: Position defines where an organization stands in competitive landscape and informs strategic choices about resource allocation, market approach, and differentiation strategy. Position types (Leader, Challenger, Follower, Nicher, Innovator, Disruptor) imply different strategic imperatives.
hasDefinedTerm.technicalMeaning: Entity linking Organization to Market with positionType classification, competitor references, strength/weakness areas, differentiators, and trend direction indicating position evolution.
hasDefinedTerm.constraints: Must reference a specific Market, positionType must be classified, marketShare (if provided) must be 0-100, assessmentDate required for tracking position changes over time.
hasDefinedTerm.relationships: Organization occupiesPosition Position, Position positionedIn Market, Position relativeToCompetitor Competitor, Capability influencesPosition Position
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use Position entities to: (1) perform competitive positioning analysis, (2) recommend positioning strategies based on capabilities, (3) identify positioning opportunities in underserved niches, (4) track position evolution and alert to declining trends, (5) compare position across multiple market segments.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Opportunity
hasDefinedTerm.description: A strategic opportunity for value creation, competitive advantage, innovation, or market expansion. Opportunities arise from identified gaps, market changes, emerging technologies, or competitive dynamics and represent potential for strategic benefit if pursued effectively.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Example: Opportunity to enter 'AI-Driven Supply Chain Optimization' market (Horizon 2), estimated $50M value over 3 years, requires 'Advanced Analytics' and 'IoT Integration' capabilities, feasibility: Medium, priority: High.
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when identifying strategic opportunities, evaluating opportunity attractiveness, prioritizing opportunities for pursuit, or planning initiatives to capture opportunities.
hasDefinedTerm.businessMeaning: Opportunities represent potential for competitive advantage and value creation. They should be evaluated based on value potential, feasibility (do we have or can we build required capabilities?), strategic fit, and time horizon. High-priority opportunities should have approved initiatives.
hasDefinedTerm.technicalMeaning: Entity with opportunityType classification, value proposition, estimated financial value, time horizon (Horizon 1/2/3 innovation framework), feasibility assessment, required capabilities, and addressed gaps. Links to Initiatives that pursue the opportunity.
hasDefinedTerm.constraints: Must have valueProposition, priority and feasibility classifications, high-priority opportunities should have estimated value (quality rule), opportunities should have required capabilities defined for feasibility assessment.
hasDefinedTerm.relationships: Gap createsOpportunity Opportunity, Opportunity requiresCapability Capability, Initiative pursuesOpportunity Opportunity
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use Opportunity entities to: (1) identify opportunities from gaps and market analysis, (2) score and rank opportunities using multi-criteria decision analysis, (3) assess opportunity feasibility by checking required capabilities, (4) recommend opportunity portfolio mix across innovation horizons, (5) trigger initiative creation for approved opportunities.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Organization
hasDefinedTerm.description: An organization (company, enterprise, institution) that possesses capabilities, occupies market positions, pursues strategic opportunities, and operates within competitive markets. Can represent your own organization, clients, competitors, partners, or acquisition targets.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Example: 'BAIV Consulting' organization (type: Self), with capabilities in 'AI Strategy', 'Digital Transformation', 'Data Architecture', operating in 'Enterprise AI Consulting' market with 'Challenger' position.
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when defining your own organization, modeling client organizations for assessment, tracking competitors, or analyzing potential partners/acquisition targets.
hasDefinedTerm.businessMeaning: Organizations are the primary actors in strategic analysis. Your organization (type: Self) is the subject of strategy formulation. Competitors are benchmarks. Clients are assessment subjects. The organization's capabilities determine what opportunities can be pursued.
hasDefinedTerm.technicalMeaning: Extends schema:Organization with organizationType classification (Self/Client/Competitor/Partner/Target), references to capabilities possessed, positions occupied in markets, technology stack, and strategic objectives.
hasDefinedTerm.constraints: Must have unique organizationId and name, organizationType required, cannot be both 'Self' and 'Competitor' type (business rule), must have at least one capability to be strategically relevant.
hasDefinedTerm.relationships: Organization hasCapability Capability, Organization occupiesPosition Position, Organization competesAgainst Competitor, Organization hasTechnologyStack Technology
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use Organization entities to: (1) perform capability benchmarking across organizations, (2) identify competitive threats and opportunities, (3) assess client maturity and readiness, (4) recommend partnership opportunities, (5) analyze technology adoption patterns.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Competitor
hasDefinedTerm.description: A competing organization in the market. Specializes Organization entity with competition-specific attributes including competitive relationship type, competitive strength, market overlap, and key strengths/weaknesses for strategic analysis.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Example: 'Tech Giants Inc.' competitor (type: Direct), competitiveStrength: Strong, market overlap in 'Enterprise AI Platform' and 'AI Consulting', key strengths: brand recognition, capital resources, key weaknesses: slower innovation cycle, enterprise bureaucracy.
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when analyzing competitive landscape, defining competitive intelligence, assessing relative position, or identifying competitive threats and opportunities.
hasDefinedTerm.businessMeaning: Competitors shape strategic choices. Direct competitors require defensive positioning and differentiation. Indirect competitors may indicate market evolution or substitution threats. Understanding competitor strengths/weaknesses informs positioning strategy and opportunity selection.
hasDefinedTerm.technicalMeaning: Specializes Organization entity with competitorType (Direct/Indirect/Potential/Substitute), competitiveStrength assessment, marketOverlap array, keyStrengths/keyWeaknesses arrays, and recentMoves for competitive intelligence tracking.
hasDefinedTerm.constraints: Must be classified by competitorType, Direct competitors should have documented market overlap (business rule), cannot be organizationType='Self' (exclusivity constraint).
hasDefinedTerm.relationships: Organization competesAgainst Competitor, Competitor competesInMarket Market, Position relativeToCompetitor Competitor
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use Competitor entities to: (1) perform automated competitive analysis and SWOT generation, (2) identify competitive threats from recent moves, (3) recommend positioning strategies relative to competitors, (4) identify partnership vs. compete decisions, (5) track competitive dynamics over time.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Market
hasDefinedTerm.description: A market segment or domain where organizations compete and position themselves. Markets have characteristics (size, growth, maturity), dynamics (trends, barriers), and competitive landscapes that influence strategic decisions.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Example: 'AI-Powered Financial Analytics' market, size: $2.5B annually, growthRate: 23% CAGR, maturity: Growth stage, key trends: regulatory compliance automation, real-time fraud detection, barriers: data quality requirements, regulatory complexity.
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when defining market segments for positioning analysis, assessing market attractiveness, identifying market opportunities, or analyzing competitive intensity within specific domains.
hasDefinedTerm.businessMeaning: Markets are arenas of competition and opportunity. Market characteristics (size, growth, maturity) determine attractiveness. High-growth, emerging markets offer opportunity but risk. Mature markets offer stability but limited growth. Market segmentation enables focused positioning.
hasDefinedTerm.technicalMeaning: Entity with marketSize (MonetaryAmount), growthRate (percentage), maturity classification (Emerging/Growth/Mature/Declining), keyTrends array, barriers array, and geographic scope. Contains positions and competitors.
hasDefinedTerm.constraints: Must have unique marketId and descriptive marketName, growthRate should be percentage, marketSize should use schema:MonetaryAmount structure when available.
hasDefinedTerm.relationships: Position positionedIn Market, Competitor competesInMarket Market
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use Market entities to: (1) assess market attractiveness for opportunity evaluation, (2) identify market entry barriers for feasibility analysis, (3) correlate market trends with opportunities, (4) segment opportunities by market, (5) recommend market prioritization based on strategic fit.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Initiative
hasDefinedTerm.description: A strategic initiative or project to address gaps, build capabilities, pursue opportunities, or drive organizational transformation. Initiatives are the execution mechanism that translates strategy into action.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Example: 'AI Center of Excellence Launch' initiative, type: Capability Building, addresses gaps in 'ML Engineering' and 'AI Governance', builds capabilities in 'Model Operations' and 'Responsible AI', budget: $2M, timeline: 18 months, status: InProgress.
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when planning strategic initiatives, tracking initiative execution, linking initiatives to gaps/opportunities they address, or managing initiative portfolio and resource allocation.
hasDefinedTerm.businessMeaning: Initiatives are how organizations close gaps and capture opportunities. Every critical gap should have an initiative. High-priority opportunities should have initiatives. Initiative portfolio should balance Horizon 1 (core), Horizon 2 (emerging), and Horizon 3 (future) investments.
hasDefinedTerm.technicalMeaning: Extends schema:Action with initiativeType classification, status tracking, budget (MonetaryAmount), timeline (startDate/endDate), and relationships to gaps addressed, opportunities pursued, and capabilities built.
hasDefinedTerm.constraints: Must have unique initiativeId and descriptive name, endDate must be after startDate (validation rule), status must be classified, critical gaps should have addressing initiatives (quality rule).
hasDefinedTerm.relationships: Initiative addressesGap Gap, Initiative pursuesOpportunity Opportunity, Initiative buildsCapability Capability
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use Initiative entities to: (1) track strategic execution and initiative portfolio, (2) identify gaps without addressing initiatives (strategic risk), (3) assess capability development progress, (4) recommend initiative prioritization and resource allocation, (5) monitor initiative status and flag at-risk initiatives.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Technology
hasDefinedTerm.description: A technology, platform, tool, or AI system that enables organizational capabilities or addresses strategic needs. Technologies are the foundational assets that make capabilities possible and determine technical feasibility of strategic initiatives.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Example: 'TensorFlow' technology, type: AI/ML Platform, vendor: Google, maturity: Mature, adoptionStatus: Standard, enables capabilities: 'Deep Learning Model Development', 'Model Training at Scale', 'Neural Network Architecture Design'.
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when documenting technology stack, assessing technology adoption maturity, identifying technology gaps, planning technology investments, or analyzing which technologies enable specific capabilities.
hasDefinedTerm.businessMeaning: Technologies are enablers of capabilities. Technology choices determine what capabilities can be built, how quickly, and at what cost. Technology maturity and adoption status impact risk and feasibility of strategic initiatives.
hasDefinedTerm.technicalMeaning: Extends schema:SoftwareApplication with technologyType classification (AI/ML Platform, Data Platform, Cloud Infrastructure, etc.), vendor, maturity assessment, adoptionStatus (NotAdopted to Deprecated lifecycle), and relationships to enabled capabilities.
hasDefinedTerm.constraints: Must have unique technologyId and descriptive name, maturity and adoptionStatus should be classified when known, technologies marked 'Standard' should enable key capabilities (quality validation).
hasDefinedTerm.relationships: Technology enablesCapability Capability, Organization hasTechnologyStack Technology
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use Technology entities to: (1) assess technical feasibility of capabilities and initiatives, (2) identify technology gaps preventing capability development, (3) recommend technology adoption priorities based on strategic needs, (4) analyze technology stack maturity and risks, (5) suggest technology consolidation or modernization opportunities.

hasDefinedTerm.name: hasCapability
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that an organization possesses or demonstrates a specific capability. Fundamental relationship for capability-based strategic analysis.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: BAIV Consulting hasCapability 'AI Strategy Formulation', 'Digital Transformation Advisory', 'Capability Assessment'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use to document organizational capabilities for internal assessment, client capability mapping, or competitive benchmarking
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to assess organizational readiness, compare capability portfolios across organizations, and identify capability-based competitive advantages or disadvantages

hasDefinedTerm.name: revealsGap
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that a capability assessment reveals a gap between current and desired state. Core relationship for gap analysis.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Capability 'ML Model Explainability' revealsGap 'Lack of Interpretability Framework' (current: basic logging, target: stakeholder dashboards)
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use during capability assessment to document shortfalls, during strategic planning to identify areas requiring investment
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to automatically identify gaps during capability assessment, prioritize gaps by associated capability importance, and recommend gap closure initiatives

hasDefinedTerm.name: createsOpportunity
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that an identified gap creates or implies a strategic opportunity for improvement, innovation, or competitive advantage.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (gaps can create multiple opportunities, opportunities can address multiple gaps)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Gap 'No Real-Time Analytics Capability' createsOpportunity 'Enter Real-Time Customer Intelligence Market'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use during opportunity identification to link opportunities to underlying gaps, during strategic planning to ensure opportunities address real needs
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to infer opportunities from gaps, assess opportunity relevance based on gap severity, and ensure opportunity-gap traceability

hasDefinedTerm.name: requiresCapability
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that an opportunity requires specific capabilities to be pursued successfully. Critical for opportunity feasibility assessment.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (opportunities require multiple capabilities, capabilities enable multiple opportunities)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Opportunity 'Launch AI Ethics Consulting Practice' requiresCapability 'Responsible AI Framework Development', 'AI Risk Assessment', 'Stakeholder Communication'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use during opportunity evaluation to assess feasibility, during capability planning to understand strategic value of capabilities
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to assess opportunity feasibility by checking if required capabilities exist at sufficient maturity, prioritize capability development based on opportunities enabled, and recommend capability investments

hasDefinedTerm.name: occupiesPosition
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that an organization occupies a specific strategic position in a market or capability domain.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: 1:* (one organization can occupy positions in multiple markets)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: BAIV Consulting occupiesPosition 'Challenger in AI Strategy Consulting', 'Nicher in Ontology-Driven AI Architecture'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use during competitive positioning analysis, market strategy formulation, differentiation planning
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to analyze competitive positioning across multiple markets, identify positioning opportunities in underserved segments, and recommend positioning strategies

hasDefinedTerm.name: positionedIn
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that a strategic position exists within a specific market segment. Every position must reference a market context.
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Position 'Leader in Enterprise AI Platforms' positionedIn Market 'Enterprise AI Software'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use to contextualize positions within markets, enable market-specific competitive analysis
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to segment competitive analysis by market, identify markets where organization lacks positioning, and recommend market entry/exit strategies

hasDefinedTerm.name: competesAgainst
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that an organization competes against a specific competitor. Fundamental relationship for competitive analysis.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (organizations compete against multiple competitors, competitors compete with multiple organizations)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: BAIV Consulting competesAgainst 'Big4 Consulting Firms', 'Specialized AI Consultancies', 'Tech Company Consulting Arms'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use to define competitive landscape, identify direct and indirect competitors, map competitive relationships
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to identify competitive set, analyze competitive dynamics, recommend competitive strategies, and alert to new competitive threats

hasDefinedTerm.name: relativeToCompetitor
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that a position is assessed relative to specific competitors. Enables comparative competitive analysis.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (positions can reference multiple competitors for comparison)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Position 'Challenger' relativeToCompetitor 'Market Leader XYZ' (positioned between leader and fast followers)
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use when defining position relative to specific competitors, conducting head-to-head competitive analysis
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to perform relative competitive analysis, identify positioning gaps vs specific competitors, and recommend competitive response strategies

hasDefinedTerm.name: competesInMarket
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that a competitor operates in a specific market segment. Defines market overlap and competitive scope.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (competitors operate in multiple markets, markets have multiple competitors)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Competitor 'TechCorp AI Division' competesInMarket 'Enterprise AI Platforms', 'AI Consulting Services', 'AI Training & Education'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use to map competitive landscape by market, identify markets with high competitive intensity, find uncontested market spaces
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to assess competitive intensity by market, identify crowded vs blue ocean markets, and recommend market selection strategies

hasDefinedTerm.name: dependsOnCapability
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that a capability depends on other foundational capabilities. Critical for capability roadmap planning and dependency management.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (capabilities have multiple dependencies, capabilities support multiple dependent capabilities)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Capability 'Advanced ML Model Development' dependsOnCapability 'Data Engineering', 'Statistical Analysis', 'Programming (Python/R)'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use during capability planning to identify prerequisite capabilities, during initiative planning to sequence capability development
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to map capability dependency graphs, identify foundational capabilities for investment priority, validate capability development sequences, and detect circular dependencies (which are invalid)

hasDefinedTerm.name: enabledByTechnology
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that a capability is enabled or supported by specific technologies. Links strategic capabilities to technical implementation.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (capabilities use multiple technologies, technologies enable multiple capabilities)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Capability 'Real-Time Predictive Analytics' enabledByTechnology 'Apache Kafka', 'TensorFlow Serving', 'Kubernetes', 'PostgreSQL'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use to map technology stack to capabilities, assess technical dependencies, identify technology gaps blocking capability development
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to assess technical feasibility of capabilities, identify technology gaps preventing capability realization, recommend technology investments based on strategic capabilities, and analyze technology rationalization opportunities

hasDefinedTerm.name: addressesGap
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that an initiative addresses or closes a specific gap. Links strategy execution to strategic needs.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (initiatives can address multiple gaps, gaps can be addressed by multiple initiatives)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Initiative 'AI Governance Framework Implementation' addressesGap 'No Responsible AI Policy', 'Lack of Model Risk Management', 'Insufficient AI Transparency'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use during initiative planning to link initiatives to gaps, during portfolio management to ensure all critical gaps are addressed
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to identify gaps without addressing initiatives (strategic risk), track gap closure progress through initiative status, and recommend initiative creation for unaddressed gaps

hasDefinedTerm.name: pursuesOpportunity
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that an initiative pursues a strategic opportunity. Links strategy execution to strategic opportunities.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (initiatives can pursue multiple opportunities, opportunities can be pursued by multiple initiatives)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Initiative 'AI Ethics Consulting Practice Launch' pursuesOpportunity 'Emerging Demand for Responsible AI Advisory', 'Differentiation Through Ethics Leadership'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use during initiative planning to link initiatives to opportunities, during portfolio management to ensure high-priority opportunities have initiatives
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to identify opportunities without pursuing initiatives, track opportunity realization through initiative outcomes, and recommend initiative creation for approved opportunities

hasDefinedTerm.name: buildsCapability
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that an initiative builds or enhances a specific capability. Links initiatives to capability development outcomes.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (initiatives build multiple capabilities, capabilities can be built by multiple initiatives)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Initiative 'AI Center of Excellence Setup' buildsCapability 'ML Engineering', 'Model Operations (MLOps)', 'AI Governance', 'Cross-Functional AI Teams'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use during initiative planning to define capability development outcomes, during capability planning to identify initiatives building specific capabilities
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to track capability development progress, identify capabilities with insufficient investment, and recommend initiatives for capability building based on strategic needs

hasDefinedTerm.name: hasTechnologyStack
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that an organization has a technology stack (collection of technologies). Defines technical capability foundation.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: 1:* (one organization has multiple technologies in its stack)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Organization 'BAIV Consulting' hasTechnologyStack 'AWS', 'Python', 'TensorFlow', 'Neo4j', 'Claude AI'
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use to document technology inventory, assess technology stack maturity, identify technology standardization opportunities
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to analyze technology portfolio, identify technology gaps vs capability needs, recommend technology consolidation or expansion, and benchmark technology adoption against competitors

hasDefinedTerm.name: influencesPosition
hasDefinedTerm.description: Relationship indicating that a capability influences competitive position (as strength or weakness). Links capabilities to positioning outcomes.
hasDefinedTerm.cardinality: *:* (capabilities influence multiple positions, positions influenced by multiple capabilities)
hasDefinedTerm.usageExample: Capability 'Ontology-Driven AI Architecture' (high maturity) influencesPosition 'Nicher in Semantic AI' as key differentiator and strength
hasDefinedTerm.usageContext: Use during competitive analysis to link capabilities to positioning, during capability planning to understand strategic impact of capabilities
hasDefinedTerm.aiAgentUsage: AI agents use this relationship to assess how capabilities drive competitive position, identify capability investments that improve position, and recommend capability development for positioning goals
